abstract.p: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Tumbleweeds Texas Barbecue in Hampton Bays, Long Island, NY; photo (M)

block.p: IT'S not Hampton Bays most people think of when they discuss ''the Hamptons,'' nor is Tumbleweeds Texas Barbecue on their mind when they extol the virtues of Hamptons restaurants.

Tumbleweeds is a contrarian. Although chic-chic glamour palaces in Southampton and East Hampton serve light, creative, cutting-edge concoctions that emphasize seafood, vegetables and fruits, Tumbleweeds has, since it opened late last year, been turning out huge portions of smoky, fat-filled, high-calorie and high-cholesterol ribs, brisket, pork and sausage for delighted barbecue fans.
IT'S not Hampton Bays most people think of when they discuss ''the Hamptons,'' nor is Tumbleweeds Texas Barbecue on their mind when they extol the virtues of Hamptons restaurants.

Tumbleweeds is a contrarian. Although chic-chic glamour palaces in Southampton and East Hampton serve light, creative, cutting-edge concoctions that emphasize seafood, vegetables and fruits, Tumbleweeds has, since it opened late last year, been turning out huge portions of smoky, fat-filled, high-calorie and high-cholesterol ribs, brisket, pork and sausage for delighted barbecue fans.

Tumbleweeds, at 174 East Montauk Highway (631-728-0808), may be the only restaurant in the Hamptons without salmon (or fish of any kind), nor is there a green vegetable to speak of (steer clear of the vinegar-doused iceberg lettuce salad).

The Texas State flags in front of this down-home spot and the saddles, spittoons, cowboy hats, boots, lassoes, chaps and stirrups inside on the barroom wall tell the story. This is not the place to order cappuccino; someone at my table did and the waitress had to fight off hysterical laughter. Rather, the focus is on the barbecue pit or, more accurately, on two large, in-the-wall smoker ovens that together rotate 2,500 pounds of meat Ferris wheel-style through the hot, dense smoke for 4 to 18 hours. That might not be a big deal in Texas where barbecue joints abound and beef, pork and poultry are sometimes cooked for as long as 35 hours, but Nassau-Suffolk is a barbecue wasteland where meat and smoke rarely meet.

As a rule, ribs are routinely cooked on a grill and slathered with some bottled barbecue sauce just before being served. By contrast, the slow cooking over hickory and fruit woods at Tumbleweeds results in a delicious marriage of smoke, meat, dry rubs and sauces.

The weight of the meat on the hefty, crusty fat-trimmed Lundy ribs ($12.95) from North Carolina often causes the soft beef to fall from the bone. Crisp skinned chicken ($12.95), with mouth-watering, moist white as well as dark meat, and the not too smoky, pulled pork ($12.95) spouting with juice will have you licking your manicured fingers. Only the slightly dry brisket ($12.95) falls a little short of true Texas transcendental. All four of these platters from the pit, as well as a super sampler for two ($24.95), are escorted by fresh, broadly cut homemade coleslaw, molasses-laced bowls of tiny baked beans that even bean haters enjoyed and tangy tomato-based sauce that's lively but not hot or thick.

Although beef ribs are a mainstay at Texas barbecue hangouts, many of the legendary ones, including Angelo's in Fort Worth and Hammond's in Glen Rose, also offer smoky pork ribs. They would be a welcome addition to Tumbleweeds limited (four) from-the-pit possibilities.

Thin-sliced, tender, carved ham ($9.95), accompanied by a robust mustard sauce and a big batch of super-fat skins-on steak fries, will appeal to those who want taste without a bold smoky overlay. Not nearly as subtle is the big, spicy flavor bang generated by the Yankee bean chili ($4.95 and $3.50). It lives in your mouth for a few minutes and in your memory for even longer. The smoked brisket sandwich ($5.50 or $7.95 with fries and coleslaw) on a hero-sized roll is improved by covering the meat with plenty of that tangy barbecue sauce.

Three side dishes ($2.95) -- an interesting, though slightly dry potato salad (egg bits, onions, green peppers), a creamy macaroni salad free of preservatives and moist squares of jalapeno-flecked corn bread -- are available on the a la carte menu. Jalapeno poppers ($4), which are breaded peppers (without their incendiary seeds) stuffed with cheddar cheese and deep fried, sound more exciting than they taste, but a ton of moist, somewhat hot, somewhat sweet farmer's sausage ($4.50) in broth is a savory starter that can feed four.

Homemade whipped cream appears with all desserts ($4 and $5), the best of which is warm apple pie with a delicate crust and ripe fruit. A fluffy, chocolate bread pudding was marred by rubbery ribbons of crust, and rice pudding was unexciting. More impressive by far is the beginning of the meal when complementary fresh, runny, home-made salsa (jalapeno, tomato, lime, cayenne and cilantro) comes with warm chips.

Tumbleweeds is enough of a funky, one-of-a-kind spot to qualify as an authentic down-and-dirty barbecue. Patrons step down into it. The very plain dining area is barnlike, the neon signs in the window are sufficiently garish, the waitresses are homey-nice and they keep the very necessary napkins and cold water coming. All of which is already attracting an enthusiastic, blue-collar crowd and might even entice some non-conformists from the tonier East to cross the Shinnecock Canal before the season ends.

The 150-seat Eastern Strawberry Chinese Buffet, at 115 Soundview Market Place in Port Washington (516-883-8150), opened in late March. It offers more than 48 hot dishes and a cold buffet of Chinese, Japanese, Italian and American dishes. Its owners plan to open the Village Chinese Buffet on Route 110 in Huntington in the near future.

The Happy Wok, a Japanese-Chinese sit-down-takeout spot, opened at 780 Fort Salonga Road (Route 25A) in Northport (631-754-1688) in April. Its owner, Jennifer Liu, who also operates the Mid China Restaurant in Commack, is offering an extensive menu of Chinese dishes (all priced under $10) and a smaller Japanese bill of fare that tops out at $14.95 (sushi and sashimi combo or teriyaki seafood special).
